ï»¿TESS OF [THE D'URBERVILLES

A Pure Woman]440-the d'urbervilles a pure woman

Faithfully presented by

[THOMAS HARDY

Contents]175-thomas hardy contents

Phase the First : [The Maiden]441-the maiden , [I]0-i - XI

Phase the Second : [Maiden]176-maiden No More , XII - XV

Phase the Third : The Rally , XVI - XXIV

Phase the Fourth : The Consequence , XXV - XXXIV

Phase the Fifth : [The Woman Pays , XXXV - XLIV

Phase the First : [The Maiden]441-the maiden

[I]0-i

On an evening in the latter part of May [a middle - aged man]445-a middle - aged man was walking homeward from [Shaston]2-shaston to [the village of Marlott]446-the village of marlott , in [the adjoining [Vale of Blakemore]3-vale of blakemore , or [Blackmoor]4-blackmoor]447-the adjoining vale of blakemore , or blackmoor . The pair of legs that carried [him]445-a middle - aged man were rickety , and there was a bias in [his]445-a middle - aged man gait which inclined [him]445-a middle - aged man somewhat to the left of a straight line . [He]445-a middle - aged man occasionally gave a smart nod , as if in confirmation of some opinion , though [he]445-a middle - aged man was not thinking of anything in particular . An empty egg - basket was slung upon [his]445-a middle - aged man arm , the nap of [his]445-a middle - aged man hat was ruffled , a patch being quite worn away at its brim where [his]445-a middle - aged man thumb came in taking it off . Presently [he]445-a middle - aged man was met by [an elderly parson astride on a gray mare , who , as [he]445-a middle - aged man rode]448-an elderly parson astride on a gray mare , who , as he rode , hummed a wandering tune .

" Good night t'ee , "[449-the man with the basket] said [the man with the basket]449-the man with the basket .

" Good night , [Sir John]177-sir john , "[450-the parson] said [the parson]450-the parson .

[The pedestrian , after another pace or two]451-the pedestrian , after another pace or two , halted , and turned round .

" Now , [sir]5821-sir , begging [your]5821-sir pardon ; [we]5822-we met last market - day on [this road]5823-this road about this time , and [I]451-the pedestrian , after another pace or two said ' Good night , ' and [you]5821-sir made reply ' Good night , [Sir John]177-sir john , ' as now . "[451-the pedestrian , after another pace or two]

" [I]450-the parson did , "[450-the parson] said [the parson]450-the parson .

" And once before that - near a month ago . "[451-the pedestrian , after another pace or two]

" [I]451-the pedestrian , after another pace or two may have . "[451-the pedestrian , after another pace or two]

" Then what might [your]5821-sir meaning be in calling [me]451-the pedestrian , after another pace or two ' [Sir John]5824-sir john ' these different times , when [I]451-the pedestrian , after another pace or two be plain [Jack Durbeyfield]178-jack durbeyfield , [the haggler]5825-the haggler ? "[451-the pedestrian , after another pace or two]

[The parson]450-the parson rode a step or two nearer .

" It was only [my]450-the parson whim , "[450-the parson] [he]450-the parson said ; and , after a moment 's hesitation : " It was on account of a discovery [I]450-the parson made some little time ago , whilst [I]450-the parson was hunting up pedigrees for the new county history . [I]450-the parson am [Parson Tringham]179-parson tringham , [the antiquary]5826-the antiquary , of [Stagfoot Lane]54-stagfoot lane . Do n't [you]5821-sir really know , [Durbeyfield]180-mrs durbeyfield , that [you]5821-sir are [the lineal representative of [the ancient and knightly family of the d'Urbervilles]5828-the ancient and knightly family of the d'urbervilles , who derive [their]5828-the ancient and knightly family of the d'urbervilles descent from [Sir Pagan d'Urberville]181-sir pagan d'urberville , [that renowned knight who came from [Normandy]6-normandy with [William the Conqueror]182-william the conqueror , as appears by [Battle Abbey Roll]7-battle abbey roll]5829-that renowned knight who came from normandy with william the conqueror , as appears by battle abbey roll]5827-the lineal representative of the ancient and knightly family of the d'urbervilles , who derive their descent from sir pagan d'urberville , that renowned knight who came from normandy with william the conqueror , as appears by battle abbey roll ? "[450-the parson]

" Never heard it before , [sir]5821-sir ! "[451-the pedestrian , after another pace or two]

" Well it 's true . Throw up [your]5821-sir chin a moment , so that [I]450-the parson may catch the profile of [your]5821-sir face better . Yes , that 's the d'Urberville nose and chin - a little debased . [[Your]5821-sir ancestor]5831-your ancestor was [one of the twelve knights who assisted [the Lord of [Estremavilla]8-estremavilla in [Normandy]6-normandy in [his]5833-the lord of estremavilla in normandy in his conquest of glamorganshire conquest of [Glamorganshire]9-glamorganshire]5833-the lord of estremavilla in normandy in his conquest of glamorganshire]5832-one of the twelve knights who assisted the lord of estremavilla in normandy in his conquest of glamorganshire . [Branches of [[your]5821-sir family]5835-your family]5834-branches of your family held manors over [all this part of [England]10-england]5836-all this part of england ; [their]5834-branches of your family names appear in the Pipe Rolls in the time of [King Stephen]183-king stephen . In the reign of [King John]184-king john one of [them]5834-branches of your family was rich enough to give [a manor]5837-a manor to [the Knights Hospitallers]185-the knights hospitallers ; and in [Edward the Second]186-edward the second 's time [[your]5821-sir forefather]5838-your forefather [Brian]187-brian was summoned to [Westminster]11-westminster to attend the great Council [there]5839-there . [You]5821-sir declined a little in [Oliver Cromwell]188-oliver cromwell 's time , but to no serious extent , and in [Charles the Second]189-charles the second 's reign [you]5821-sir were made [Knights of the Royal Oak]5840-knights of the royal oak for [your]5821-sir loyalty . Aye , there have been generations of [Sir Johns]190-sir johns among [you]5821-sir , and if knighthood were hereditary , like a baronetcy , as it practically was in old times , when [men]5841-men were knighted from [father]5842-father to [son]5843-son , [you]5821-sir would be [Sir John]177-sir john now . "[450-the parson]

" [Ye]5821-sir do n't say so ! "[451-the pedestrian , after another pace or two]

" In short , "[450-the parson] concluded [the parson]450-the parson , decisively smacking [his]450-the parson leg with [his]450-the parson switch , " there 's hardly [such another family in [England]10-england]5844-such another family in england . "[450-the parson]

" Daze [my]180-mrs durbeyfield eyes , and is n't [there]5839-there ? "[180-mrs durbeyfield] said [Durbeyfield]180-mrs durbeyfield . " And here have [I]180-mrs durbeyfield been knocking about , year after year , from pillar to post , as if [I]180-mrs durbeyfield was no more than [the commonest feller in [the parish]5847-the parish]5846-the commonest feller in the parish ... And how long [hev]180-mrs durbeyfield this news about [me]180-mrs durbeyfield been knowed , [Pa'son Tringham]191-pa'son tringham ? "[180-mrs durbeyfield]

[The clergyman]455-the clergyman explained that , as far as [he]455-the clergyman was aware , it had quite died out of knowledge , and could hardly be said to be known at all . [His]455-the clergyman own investigations had begun on a day in the preceding spring when , having been engaged in tracing the vicissitudes of [the d'Urberville family]456-the d'urberville family , [he]455-the clergyman had observed [Durbeyfield]180-mrs durbeyfield 's name on [his]455-the clergyman waggon , and had thereupon been led to make inquiries about [[his]455-the clergyman father]457-his father and [grandfather]458-grandfather till [he]455-the clergyman had no doubt on the subject .

" At first [I]455-the clergyman resolved not to disturb [you]455-the clergyman with such a useless piece of information , "[455-the clergyman] said [he]455-the clergyman . " However , [our]5848-we impulses are too strong for [our]5848-we judgement sometimes . [I]455-the clergyman thought [you]455-the clergyman might perhaps know something of it all the while . "[455-the clergyman]

" Well , [I]180-mrs durbeyfield have heard once or twice , ' tis true , that [[my]180-mrs durbeyfield family]5849-my family had seen better days afore [they]5849-my family came to [Blackmoor]4-blackmoor . But [I]180-mrs durbeyfield took no notice o't , thinking it to mean that [we]5848-we had once kept two horses where [we]5848-we now keep only one . [I]180-mrs durbeyfield 've got a wold silver spoon , and a wold graven seal at [home]5850-home , too ; but , [Lord]5851-lord , what 's a spoon and seal ? ... And to think that [I]180-mrs durbeyfield and [these noble d'Urbervilles]5852-these noble d'urbervilles were [one flesh]5853-one flesh all the time . ' Twas said that [[my]180-mrs durbeyfield gr't - granfer]5854-my gr't - granfer had secrets , and did n't care to talk of where [he]5854-my gr't - granfer came from ... And where do [we]5848-we raise [our]5848-we smoke , now , [parson]5855-parson , if [I]180-mrs durbeyfield may make so bold ; [I]180-mrs durbeyfield mean , where do [we]5848-we d'Urbervilles live ? "[180-mrs durbeyfield]

" [You]5855-parson do n't live anywhere . [You]5855-parson are extinct - as [a county family]5856-a county family . "[455-the clergyman]

" That 's bad . "[180-mrs durbeyfield]

" Yes - what the mendacious family chronicles call extinct in the male line - that is , gone down - gone under . "[455-the clergyman]

" Then where do [we]5848-we lie ? "[180-mrs durbeyfield]

" At [Kingsbere]12-kingsbere - [sub - [Greenhill]13-greenhill]5857-sub - greenhill : rows and rows of [you]5855-parson in [[your]5855-parson vaults]5858-your vaults , with [your]5855-parson effigies under Purbeck - marble canopies . "[455-the clergyman]

" And where be [[our]5848-we family mansions and [estates]5860-estates]5859-our family mansions and estates ? "[180-mrs durbeyfield]

" [You]5855-parson have n't any . "[455-the clergyman]

" Oh ? [No lands]5861-no lands neither ? "[180-mrs durbeyfield]

" None ; though [you]5855-parson once had 'em in abundance , as [I]455-the clergyman said , for [[you]5855-parson family]5862-you family consisted of numerous branches . In [this county]5863-this county there was [a seat of yours at [Kingsbere]12-kingsbere]5864-a seat of yours at kingsbere , and another at [Sherton]14-sherton , and another in [Millpond]15-millpond , and another at [Lullstead]16-lullstead , and another at [Wellbridge]17-wellbridge . "[455-the clergyman]

" And shall [we]5848-we ever come into [our]5848-we own again ? "[180-mrs durbeyfield]

" Ah - that [I]455-the clergyman ca n't tell ! "[455-the clergyman]

" And what had [I]180-mrs durbeyfield better do about it , [sir]5821-sir ? "[180-mrs durbeyfield] asked [Durbeyfield]180-mrs durbeyfield , after a pause .

" Oh - nothing , nothing ; except chasten [yourself]5855-parson with the thought of ' how are the mighty fallen . ' It is a fact of some interest to [the local historian]5866-the local historian and [genealogist]5867-genealogist , nothing more . There are [several families among [the cottagers of [this county of almost equal lustre]5870-this county of almost equal lustre]5869-the cottagers of this county of almost equal lustre]5868-several families among the cottagers of this county of almost equal lustre . Good night . "[455-the clergyman]

" But [you]5821-sir 'll turn back and have a quart of beer wi ' [me]455-the clergyman on the strength o't , [Pa'son Tringham]191-pa'son tringham ? There 's a very pretty brew in tap at [The Pure Drop]18-the pure drop - though , to be sure , not so good as at [Rolliver 's]211-rolliver . "[455-the clergyman]

" No , thank [you]180-mrs durbeyfield - not this evening , [Durbeyfield]180-mrs durbeyfield . [You]180-mrs durbeyfield 've had enough already . "[455-the clergyman] Concluding thus , [the parson]450-the parson rode on [his]450-the parson way , with doubts as to [his]450-the parson discretion in retailing this curious bit of lore .

When [he]450-the parson was gone , [Durbeyfield]180-mrs durbeyfield walked a few steps in a profound reverie , and then sat down upon [the grassy bank by the roadside]460-the grassy bank by the roadside , depositing [his]450-the parson basket before [him]450-the parson . In a few minutes [a youth]461-a youth appeared in the distance , walking in the same direction as that which had been pursued by [Durbeyfield]180-mrs durbeyfield . [The latter]462-the latter , on seeing [him]450-the parson , held up [his]450-the parson hand , and [the lad]463-the lad quickened [his]450-the parson pace and came near .

" [Boy]5871-boy , take up that basket ! [I]462-the latter want ' [ee]5872-ee to go on an errand for [me]462-the latter . "[462-the latter]

[The lath - like stripling]464-the lath - like stripling frowned . " Who be [you]5871-boy , then , [John Durbeyfield]192-john durbeyfield , to order [me]464-the lath - like stripling about and call [me]464-the lath - like stripling ' [boy]5871-boy ' ? [You]192-john durbeyfield know [my]464-the lath - like stripling name as well as [I]464-the lath - like stripling know [yours]192-john durbeyfield ! "[464-the lath - like stripling]

" Do [you]5871-boy , do [you]5871-boy ? That 's the secret - that 's the secret ! Now obey [my]465-i orders , and take the message [I]465-i 'm going to charge ' [ee]5872-ee wi ' ... Well , [Fred]193-fred , [I]465-i do n't mind telling [you]193-fred that the secret is that [I]465-i 'm one of [a noble race]5874-a noble race - it has been just found out by [me]465-i this present afternoon , P.M. "[465-i] And as [he]465-i made the announcement , [Durbeyfield]180-mrs durbeyfield , declining from [his]465-i sitting position , luxuriously stretched [himself]465-i out upon [the bank]466-the bank among the daisies .

[The lad]463-the lad stood before [Durbeyfield]180-mrs durbeyfield , and contemplated [his]463-the lad length from crown to toe .

" [Sir John]177-sir john d'Urberville - that 's who [I]468-the prostrate man am , "[468-the prostrate man] continued [the prostrate man]468-the prostrate man . " That is if [knights]5875-knights were [baronets]5876-baronets - which [they]5875-knights be . ' Tis recorded in history all about [me]468-the prostrate man . Dost know of such a place , [lad]5877-lad , as Kingsbere - sub - [Greenhill]13-greenhill ? "[468-the prostrate man]

" Ees . [I]465-i 've been there to [Greenhill Fair]20-greenhill fair . "[465-i]

" Well , under [the church of [that city]5879-that city]5878-the church of that city there lie - "[468-the prostrate man]

" ' Tisn't [a city]5880-a city , the place [I]465-i mean ; leastwise ' twaddn ' when [I]465-i was [there]5839-there - ' twas a little one - eyed , blinking sort o ' place . "[465-i]

" Never [you]5877-lad mind [the place]5882-the place , [boy]5871-boy , that 's not the question before [us]5884-us . Under [the church of that there parish]5885-the church of that there parish lie [[my]468-the prostrate man ancestors]5886-my ancestors - hundreds of ['em]5887-'em - in coats of mail and jewels , in gr't lead coffins weighing tons and tons . There 's [not a man in [the county]5889-the county o ' South - Wessex that 's got grander and nobler skillentons in [[his]5888-not a man in the county o ' south - wessex that 's got grander and nobler skillentons in his family family]5890-his family]5888-not a man in the county o ' south - wessex that 's got grander and nobler skillentons in his family than [I.]468-the prostrate man "[468-the prostrate man]

" Oh ? "[465-i]

" Now take up that basket , and goo on to [Marlott]21-marlott , and when [you]5877-lad 've come to [The Pure Drop Inn]5891-the pure drop inn , tell ['em]5887-'em to send [a horse and carriage]5892-a horse and carriage to [me]468-the prostrate man immed'ately , to carry [me]468-the prostrate man hwome . And in the bottom o ' [the carriage]5893-the carriage [they]5892-a horse and carriage be to put a noggin o ' rum in a small bottle , and chalk it up to [my]468-the prostrate man account . And when [you]5877-lad 've done that goo on to [[my]468-the prostrate man house]5894-my house with the basket , and tell [[my]468-the prostrate man wife]5895-my wife to put away that washing , because [she]5895-my wife need n't finish it , and wait till [I]468-the prostrate man come hwome , as [I]468-the prostrate man 've news to tell [her]5895-my wife . "[468-the prostrate man]

As [the lad]463-the lad stood in a dubious attitude , [Durbeyfield]180-mrs durbeyfield put [his]470-his hand in [his]470-his pocket , and produced a shilling , one of the chronically few that [he]470-his possessed .

" Here 's for [your]463-the lad labour , [lad]5877-lad . "[180-mrs durbeyfield]

This made a difference in [the young man]471-the young man 's estimate of the position .

" Yes , [Sir John]177-sir john . Thank ' [ee]177-sir john . Anything else [I]468-the prostrate man can do for ' ee , [Sir John]177-sir john ? "[468-the prostrate man]

" Tell ['em]177-sir john at hwome that [I]470-his should like for supper , - well , lamb 's fry if [they]5897-they can get it ; and if [they]5897-they ca n't , black - pot ; and if [they]5897-they ca n't get that , [well chitterlings]5898-well chitterlings will do . "[470-his]

" Yes , [Sir John]5824-sir john . "[468-the prostrate man]

[The boy]472-the boy took up the basket , and as [he]472-the boy set out the notes of a brass band were heard from the direction of [the village]473-the village .

" What 's that ? "[180-mrs durbeyfield] said [Durbeyfield]180-mrs durbeyfield . " Not on account o ' [I]180-mrs durbeyfield ? "[180-mrs durbeyfield]

" ' Tis [[the women]5900-the women 's club]5901-the women 's club - walking , [Sir John]177-sir john . Why , [[your]177-sir john da'ter]5902-your da'ter is one o ' [the members]5903-the members . "[470-his]

" To be sure - [I]180-mrs durbeyfield 'd quite forgot it in [my]180-mrs durbeyfield thoughts of greater things ! Well , vamp on to [Marlott]21-marlott , will [ye]177-sir john , and order [that carriage]5904-that carriage , and maybe [I]180-mrs durbeyfield 'll drive round and inspect [the club]5905-the club . "[180-mrs durbeyfield]

[The lad]463-the lad departed , and [Durbeyfield]180-mrs durbeyfield lay waiting on the grass and daisies in the evening sun . [Not a soul]475-not a soul passed that way for a long while , and the faint notes of the band were the only human sounds audible within [the rim of [blue hills]477-blue hills]476-the rim of blue hills .

II

[The village of Marlott]446-the village of marlott lay amid the north - eastern undulations of [the beautiful Vale of [Blakemore]22-blakemore]479-the beautiful vale of blakemore , or [Blackmoor]4-blackmoor , aforesaid , [an engirdled and secluded region]480-an engirdled and secluded region , for the most part untrodden as yet by [tourist or landscape - painter]481-tourist or landscape - painter , though within a four hours ' journey from [London]23-london .

[It]446-the village of marlott is [a vale whose acquaintance is best made by viewing [it]446-the village of marlott]482-a vale whose acquaintance is best made by viewing it from the summits of [the hills that surround [it]446-the village of marlott]483-the hills that surround it - except perhaps during the droughts of summer . An unguided ramble into [its]446-the village of marlott recesses in bad weather is apt to engender dissatisfaction with [its]446-the village of marlott narrow , tortuous , and miry ways .

[This fertile and sheltered tract of country , in which [the fields are never brown]485-the fields are never brown and [the springs never dry]486-the springs never dry]484-this fertile and sheltered tract of country , in which the fields are never brown and the springs never dry , is bounded on the south by the bold chalk ridge that embraces [the prominences of [Hambledon Hill]24-hambledon hill]487-the prominences of hambledon hill , [Bulbarrow]122-bulbarrow , [Nettlecombe]26-nettlecombe - Tout , [Dogbury]27-dogbury , [High Stoy]28-high stoy , and Bubb Down . [The traveller from [the coast]489-the coast , who , after plodding northward for a score of miles over [calcareous downs and corn - lands]490-calcareous downs and corn - lands , suddenly reaches the verge of [one of [these escarpments]492-these escarpments]491-one of these escarpments]488-the traveller from the coast , who , after plodding northward for a score of miles over calcareous downs and corn - lands , suddenly reaches the verge of one of these escarpments , is surprised and delighted to behold , extended like a map beneath [him]488-the traveller from the coast , who , after plodding northward for a score of miles over calcareous downs and corn - lands , suddenly reaches the verge of one of these escarpments , [a country differing absolutely from that which [he]488-the traveller from the coast , who , after plodding northward for a score of miles over calcareous downs and corn - lands , suddenly reaches the verge of one of these escarpments has passed through]493-a country differing absolutely from that which he has passed through . Behind [him]488-the traveller from the coast , who , after plodding northward for a score of miles over calcareous downs and corn - lands , suddenly reaches the verge of one of these escarpments [the hills]494-the hills are open , the sun blazes down upon fields so large as to give an unenclosed character to the landscape , [the lanes]495-the lanes are white , the hedges low and plashed , the atmosphere colourless . Here , in [the valley]496-the valley , [the world]497-the world seems to be constructed upon a smaller and more delicate scale ; [the fields]498-the fields are [mere paddocks]499-mere paddocks , so reduced that from this height [their]498-the fields hedgerows appear a network of dark green threads overspreading the paler green of the grass . The atmosphere beneath is languorous , and is so tinged with azure that what artists call the middle distance partakes also of that hue , while the horizon beyond is of the deepest ultramarine . [Arable lands]500-arable lands are few and limited ; with but slight exceptions the prospect is a broad rich mass of grass and trees , mantling [minor hills and dales within [the major]502-the major]501-minor hills and dales within the major . Such is [the Vale of Blackmoor]29-the vale of blackmoor .

[The district]503-the district is of historic , no less than of topographical interest . [The Vale]30-the vale was known in former times as [the Forest of White Hart]504-the forest of white hart , from a curious legend of [King Henry III]195-king henry iii 's reign , in which the killing by [a certain [Thomas de la Lynd]196-thomas de la lynd of a beautiful white hart which [the king]506-the king had run down and spared]505-a certain thomas de la lynd of a beautiful white hart which the king had run down and spared , was made the occasion of a heavy fine . In those days , and till comparatively recent times , [the country]507-the country was densely wooded . Even now , traces of [its]507-the country earlier condition are to be found in the old oak copses and irregular belts of timber that yet survive upon [its]507-the country slopes , and the hollow - trunked trees that shade so many of [[its]507-the country pastures]508-its pastures .

[The forests]509-the forests have departed , but some old customs of their shades remain . Many , however , linger only in a metamorphosed or disguised form . The May - Day dance , for instance , was to be discerned on the afternoon under notice , in the guise of the club revel , or " club - walking , "[510-the younger inhabitants of marlott] as it was there called .

It was an interesting event to [the younger inhabitants of [Marlott]21-marlott]510-the younger inhabitants of marlott , though its real interest was not observed by [the participators in the ceremony]511-the participators in the ceremony . Its singularity lay less in the retention of a custom of walking in procession and dancing on each anniversary than in [the members]5903-the members being [solely women]513-solely women . In [[men]5841-men 's clubs]515-men 's clubs such celebrations were , though expiring , less uncommon ; but either the natural shyness of the softer sex , or a sarcastic attitude on the part of [male relatives]516-male relatives , had denuded [such women]517-such women 's clubs as remained if any other did or this [their]515-men 's clubs glory and consummation . [The club of [Marlott]21-marlott]518-the club of marlott alone lived to uphold [the local Cerealia]519-the local cerealia . [It]518-the club of marlott had walked for hundreds of years , if not as [benefit - club]520-benefit - club , as [votive sisterhood of some sort]521-votive sisterhood of some sort ; and [it]518-the club of marlott walked still .

[The banded ones]522-the banded ones were all dressed in white gowns - a gay survival from Old Style days , when cheerfulness and May - time were synonyms - days before the habit of taking long views had reduced emotions to a monotonous average . [Their]522-the banded ones first exhibition of [themselves]522-the banded ones was in a processional march of two and two round [the parish]5847-the parish . [Ideal]197-ideal and real clashed slightly as the sun lit up [their]522-the banded ones figures against the green hedges and creeper - laced [house - fronts]524-house - fronts ; for , though [the whole troop]525-the whole troop wore white garments , [no two whites]526-no two whites were alike among [them]525-the whole troop . [Some]527-some approached pure blanching ; some had a bluish pallor ; some worn by [the older characters which had possibly lain by folded for many a year inclined to a cadaverous tint , and to a Georgian style]528-the older characters which had possibly lain by folded for many a year inclined to a cadaverous tint , and to a georgian style .

In addition to the distinction of a white frock , [every woman and girl]529-every woman and girl carried in [her]529-every woman and girl right hand a peeled willow wand , and in [her]529-every woman and girl left a bunch of white flowers . The peeling of the former , and the selection of the latter , had been an operation of personal care .

There were [a few middle - aged and even elderly women in [the train]531-the train]530-a few middle - aged and even elderly women in the train , [their]530-a few middle - aged and even elderly women in the train silver - wiry hair and wrinkled faces , scourged by time and trouble , having almost a grotesque , certainly a pathetic , appearance in such a jaunty situation . In a true view , perhaps , there was more to be gathered and told of [each anxious and experienced one]532-each anxious and experienced one , to whom the years were drawing nigh when [she]529-every woman and girl should say , " [I]529-every woman and girl have no pleasure in [them]536-the young girls , "[529-every woman and girl] than of [[her]529-every woman and girl juvenile comrades]533-her juvenile comrades . But let [the elder]534-the elder be passed over here for [those under whose bodices the life throbbed quick and warm]535-those under whose bodices the life throbbed quick and warm .

[The young girls]536-the young girls formed , indeed , [the majority of [the band]538-the band]537-the majority of the band , and [their]536-the young girls heads of luxuriant hair reflected in the sunshine every tone of gold , and black , and brown . [Some]527-some had beautiful eyes , others a beautiful nose , others a beautiful mouth and figure : [few]540-few , if any , had all . A difficulty of arranging [their]536-the young girls lips in this crude exposure to public scrutiny , an inability to balance [their]536-the young girls heads , and to dissociate self - consciousness from [their]536-the young girls features , was apparent in [them]536-the young girls , and showed that [they]536-the young girls were [genuine country girls]541-genuine country girls , unaccustomed to many eyes .

And as each and all of [them]536-the young girls were warmed without by the sun , so [each]542-each had a private little sun for [her]542-each soul to bask in ; some dream , some affection , some hobby , at least some remote and distant hope which , though perhaps starving to nothing , still lived on , as hopes will . [They]536-the young girls were all cheerful , and many of [them]536-the young girls merry .

[They]536-the young girls came round by [The Pure Drop Inn]31-the pure drop inn , and were turning out of [the high road]543-the high road to pass through a wicket - gate into [the meadows]544-the meadows , when [one of [the women]5900-the women]545-one of the women said -

" [The Load - a - Lord]5906-the load - a - lord ! Why , [Tess Durbeyfield]198-tess , if there is n't [[thy]198-tess father]5907-thy father riding hwome in [a carriage]5908-a carriage ! "[545-one of the women]

[A young member of the band]547-a young member of the band turned [her]547-a young member of the band head at the exclamation . [She]547-a young member of the band was [a fine and handsome girl]548-a fine and handsome girl - not handsomer than some others , possibly - but [her]547-a young member of the band mobile peony mouth and large innocent eyes added eloquence to colour and shape . [She]547-a young member of the band wore a red ribbon in [her]547-a young member of the band hair , and was the only one of [the white company who could boast of such a pronounced adornment]549-the white company who could boast of such a pronounced adornment . As [she]547-a young member of the band looked round [Durbeyfield]198-tess was seen moving along [the road]550-the road in a chaise belonging to [The Pure Drop]18-the pure drop , driven by [a frizzle - headed brawny damsel with [her]547-a young member of the band gown - sleeves rolled above [her]547-a young member of the band elbows]551-a frizzle - headed brawny damsel with her gown - sleeves rolled above her elbows . This was [the cheerful servant of that establishment , who , in [her]547-a young member of the band part of factotum]552-the cheerful servant of that establishment , who , in her part of factotum , turned [groom]553-groom and ostler at times . [Durbeyfield]198-tess , leaning back , and with [his]554-his eyes closed luxuriously , was waving [his]554-his hand above [his]554-his head , and singing in a slow recitative -

" [I]554-his 've -got - [a - gr't - family - vault - at - Kingsbere]5909-a - gr't - family - vault - at - kingsbere - and [knighted - forefathers - in - lead - coffins]5910-knighted - forefathers - in - lead - coffins - there ! "[554-his]

[The clubbists]555-the clubbists tittered , except [the girl called [Tess]198-tess]556-the girl called tess - in whom a slow heat seemed to rise at the sense that [[her]198-tess father]557-her father was making [himself]554-his foolish in [their]555-the clubbists eyes .

" [He]554-his 's tired , that 's all , "[198-tess] [she]198-tess said hastily , " and [he]554-his has got a lift [home]5850-home , because [our]555-the clubbists own horse has to rest to - day . "[198-tess]

" Bless [thy]198-tess simplicity , [Tess]198-tess , "[558-her companions] said [[her]198-tess companions]558-her companions . " [He]554-his 's got [his]554-his market - nitch . Haw - haw ! "[558-her companions]

" Look here ; [I]198-tess wo n't walk another inch with [you]554-his , if [you]554-his say any jokes about [him]554-his ! "[198-tess] [Tess]198-tess cried , and the colour upon [her]198-tess cheeks spread over [her]198-tess face and neck . In a moment [her]198-tess eyes grew moist , and [her]198-tess glance drooped to the ground . Perceiving that [they]559-they had really pained [her]198-tess [they]559-they said no more , and order again prevailed . [Tess]198-tess 's pride would not allow [her]198-tess to turn [her]198-tess head again , to learn what [[her]198-tess father]557-her father 's meaning was , if [he]557-her father had any ; and thus [she]198-tess moved on with the whole body to the enclosure where there was to be dancing on [the green]561-the green . By the time the spot was reached [she]198-tess has recovered [her]198-tess equanimity , and tapped [[her]198-tess neighbour]562-her neighbour with [her]198-tess wand and talked as usual .

[Tess Durbeyfield]198-tess at this time of [her]198-tess life was a mere vessel of emotion untinctured by experience . The dialect was on [her]198-tess tongue to some extent , despite [the village school]563-the village school : the characteristic intonation of that dialect for [this district]564-this district being the voicing approximately rendered by the syllable [UR]199-ur , probably as rich an utterance as any to be found in human speech . The pouted - up deep red mouth to which this syllable was native had hardly as yet settled into its definite shape , and [her]198-tess lower lip had a way of thrusting the middle of [her]198-tess top one upward , when they closed together after a word .

Phases of [her]198-tess childhood lurked in [her]198-tess aspect still . As [she]198-tess walked along to - day , for all [her]198-tess bouncing handsome womanliness , [you]565-you could sometimes see [her]198-tess twelfth year in [her]198-tess cheeks , or [her]198-tess ninth sparkling from [her]198-tess eyes ; and even [her]198-tess fifth would flit over the curves of [her]198-tess mouth now and then .

Yet [few]540-few knew , and still fewer considered this . [A small minority]567-a small minority , mainly [strangers]568-strangers , would look long at [her]198-tess in casually passing by , and grow momentarily fascinated by [her]198-tess freshness , and wonder if [they]567-a small minority would ever see [her]198-tess again : but to almost [everybody]569-everybody [she]198-tess was [a fine and picturesque country girl]570-a fine and picturesque country girl , and no more .

Nothing was seen or heard further of [Durbeyfield]198-tess in [his]571-his triumphal chariot under the conduct of [the ostleress]572-the ostleress , and [the club]5905-the club having entered [the allotted space]574-the allotted space , dancing began . As there were [no men in the company]575-no men in the company , [the girls]576-the girls danced at first with [each other]577-each other , but when the hour for the close of labour drew on , [the masculine inhabitants of [the village]473-the village]578-the masculine inhabitants of the village , together with [other idlers]580-other idlers and [pedestrians]581-pedestrians , gathered round the spot , and appeared inclined to negotiate for [a partner]582-a partner .

Among [these on - lookers]583-these on - lookers were [three young men of a superior class]584-three young men of a superior class , carrying small knapsacks strapped to [their]584-three young men of a superior class shoulders , and stout sticks in [their]584-three young men of a superior class hands . [Their]584-three young men of a superior class general likeness to [each other]577-each other , and [their]584-three young men of a superior class consecutive ages , would almost have suggested that [they]584-three young men of a superior class might be , what in fact [they]584-three young men of a superior class were , [brothers]586-brothers . [The eldest]587-the eldest wore the white tie , high waistcoat , and thin - brimmed hat of [the regulation curate]588-the regulation curate ; [the second]589-the second was [the normal undergraduate]590-the normal undergraduate ; the appearance of [the third and youngest]591-the third and youngest would hardly have been sufficient to characterize [him]589-the second ; there was an uncribbed , uncabined aspect in [his]589-the second eyes and attire , implying that [he]589-the second had hardly as yet found the entrance to [his]589-the second professional groove . That [he]589-the second was [a desultory tentative student of something]592-a desultory tentative student of something and everything might only have been predicted of [him]589-the second .

[These three brethren]593-these three brethren told [casual acquaintance]594-casual acquaintance that [they]593-these three brethren were spending [their]593-these three brethren Whitsun holidays in a walking tour through [the Vale of Blackmoor]595-the vale of blackmoor , [their]593-these three brethren course being south - westerly from [the town of Shaston]596-the town of shaston on [the north - east]597-the north - east .

[They]593-these three brethren leant over the gate by [the highway]598-the highway , and inquired as to the meaning of the dance and [the white - frocked maids]599-the white - frocked maids . [The two elder of [the brothers]601-the brothers]600-the two elder of the brothers were plainly not intending to linger more than a moment , but the spectacle of [a bevy of girls]602-a bevy of girls dancing without [male partners]603-male partners seemed to amuse [the third]604-the third , and make [him]604-the third in no hurry to move on . [He]604-the third unstrapped [his]604-the third knapsack , put it , with [his]604-the third stick , on the hedge - bank , and opened the gate .

" What are [you]606-the first going to do , [Angel]200-clare ? "[587-the eldest] asked [the eldest]587-the eldest .

" [I]604-the third am inclined to go and have a fling with [them]601-the brothers . Why not all of [us]601-the brothers - just for a minute or two - it will not detain [us]601-the brothers long ? "[604-the third]

" No - no ; nonsense ! "[606-the first] said [the first]606-the first . " Dancing in public with [a troop of [country hoydens]5913-country hoydens]5912-a troop of country hoydens - suppose [we]601-the brothers should be seen ! Come along , or it will be dark before [we]601-the brothers get to [Stourcastle]32-stourcastle , and there 's no place [we]601-the brothers can sleep at nearer than that ; besides , [we]601-the brothers must get through another chapter of A Counterblast to Agnosticism before [we]601-the brothers turn in , now [I]606-the first have taken the trouble to bring the book . "[606-the first]

" All right - [I]606-the first 'll overtake [you]607-the two elder and [Cuthbert]201-cuthbert in five minutes ; do n't stop ; [I]606-the first give [my]606-the first word that [I]606-the first will , [Felix]202-felix . "[606-the first]

[The two elder]607-the two elder reluctantly left [him]606-the first and walked on , taking [[their]607-the two elder brother]608-their brother 's knapsack to relieve [him]606-the first in following , and [the youngest]609-the youngest entered [the field]610-the field .

" This is a thousand pities , "[606-the first] [he]606-the first said gallantly , to [two or three of [the girls nearest [him]606-the first]612-the girls nearest him]611-two or three of the girls nearest him , as soon as there was a pause in the dance . " Where are [[your]607-the two elder partners]5914-your partners , [[my]606-the first dears]5915-my dears ? "[606-the first]

" [They]5914-your partners 've not left off work yet , "[609-the youngest] answered one of the boldest . " [They]5914-your partners 'll be here by and by . Till then , will [you]471-the young man be one , [sir]5821-sir ? "[609-the youngest]

" Certainly . But what 's one among so many ! "[606-the first]

" Better than none . ' Tis melancholy work facing and footing it to one of [your]471-the young man own sort , and no clipsing and colling at all . Now , pick and choose . "[609-the youngest]

" ' Ssh - do n't be so for'ard ! "[613-a shyer girl] said [a shyer girl]613-a shyer girl .

[The young man]471-the young man , thus invited , glanced [them]615-them over , and attempted some discrimination ; but , as [the group]616-the group were all so new to [him]471-the young man , [he]471-the young man could not very well exercise it . [He]471-the young man took almost the first that came to hand , which was not [the speaker]617-the speaker , as [she]613-a shyer girl had expected ; nor did it happen to be [Tess Durbeyfield]198-tess . Pedigree , [ancestral skeletons]618-ancestral skeletons , monumental record , the d'Urberville lineaments , did not help [Tess]198-tess in [her]198-tess life 's battle as yet , even to the extent of attracting to [her]198-tess a dancing - partner over [the heads of [the commonest peasantry]620-the commonest peasantry]619-the heads of the commonest peasantry . So much for [Norman]203-norman blood unaided by Victorian lucre .

The name of [the eclipsing girl]621-the eclipsing girl , whatever it was , has not been handed down ; but [she]621-the eclipsing girl was envied by [all]622-all as the first who enjoyed the luxury of [a masculine partner]623-a masculine partner that evening . Yet such was the force of example that [the village young men]624-the village young men , who had not hastened to enter the gate while [no intruder was in the way]625-no intruder was in the way , now dropped in quickly , and soon [the couples]626-the couples became leavened with rustic youth to a marked extent , till at length [the plainest woman in the club]627-the plainest woman in the club was no longer compelled to foot it on the masculine side of the figure .

The church clock struck , when suddenly [the student]628-the student said that [he]471-the young man must leave - [he]471-the young man had been forgetting [himself]471-the young man - [he]471-the young man had to join [[his]471-the young man companions]629-his companions . As [he]471-the young man fell out of the dance [his]471-the young man eyes lighted on [Tess Durbeyfield]198-tess , whose own large orbs wore , to tell the truth , the faintest aspect of reproach that [he]471-the young man had not chosen [her]198-tess . [He]471-the young man , too , was sorry then that , owing to [her]198-tess backwardness , [he]471-the young man had not observed [her]198-tess ; and with that in [his]471-the young man mind [he]471-the young man left [the pasture]630-the pasture .

On account of [his]471-the young man long delay [he]471-the young man started in a flying - run down [the lane]631-the lane westward , and had soon passed [the hollow]632-the hollow and mounted [the next rise]633-the next rise . [He]471-the young man had not yet overtaken [[his]471-the young man brothers]634-his brothers , but [he]471-the young man paused to get breath , and looked back . [He]471-the young man could see the white figures of [the girls in the green enclosure]635-the girls in the green enclosure whirling about as [they]635-the girls in the green enclosure had whirled when [he]471-the young man was among [them]635-the girls in the green enclosure . [They]635-the girls in the green enclosure seemed to have quite forgotten [him]471-the young man already .

All of [them]635-the girls in the green enclosure , except , perhaps , one . This white shape stood apart by the hedge alone . From [her]636-her position [he]471-the young man knew it to be [the pretty maiden with whom [he]471-the young man had not danced]637-the pretty maiden with whom he had not danced . Trifling as the matter was , [he]471-the young man yet instinctively felt that [she]636-her was hurt by [his]471-the young man oversight . [He]471-the young man wished that [he]471-the young man had asked [her]636-her ; [he]471-the young man wished that [he]471-the young man had inquired [her]636-her name . [She]636-her was so modest , so expressive , [she]636-her had looked so soft in [her]636-her thin white gown that [he]471-the young man felt [he]471-the young man had acted stupidly .

However , it could not be helped , and turning , and bending [himself]471-the young man to a rapid walk , [he]471-the young man dismissed the subject from [his]471-the young man mind .

[III]195-king henry iii

As for [Tess Durbeyfield]198-tess , [she]636-her did not so easily dislodge the incident from [her]636-her consideration . [She]636-her had no spirit to dance again for a long time , though [she]636-her might have had plenty of [partners]638-partners ; but ah ! [they]639-they did not speak so nicely as [the strange young man]640-the strange young man had done . It was not till the rays of the sun had absorbed [the young stranger]641-the young stranger 's retreating figure on [the hill]642-the hill that [she]636-her shook off [her]636-her temporary sadness and answered [her]636-her would - be partner in the affirmative .

[She]636-her remained with [[her]636-her comrades]643-her comrades till dusk , and participated with a certain zest in the dancing ; though , being heart - whole as yet , [she]636-her enjoyed treading a measure purely for its own sake ; little divining when [she]636-her saw " the soft torments , the bitter sweets , the pleasing pains , and the agreeable distresses "[636-her] of [those girls who had been wooed and won]644-those girls who had been wooed and won , what [she]636-her [herself]636-her was capable of in that kind . The struggles and wrangles of [the lads]645-the lads for [her]636-her hand in a jig were an amusement to [her]636-her - no more ; and when [they]639-they became fierce [she]636-her rebuked [them]639-they .

[She]636-her might have stayed even later , but the incident of [[her]636-her father]557-her father 's odd appearance and manner returned upon [the girl]647-the girl 's mind to make [her]636-her anxious , and wondering what had become of [him]557-her father [she]636-her dropped away from [the dancers]648-the dancers and bent [her]636-her steps towards [the end of [the village at which [the parental cottage]651-the parental cottage lay]650-the village at which the parental cottage lay]649-the end of the village at which the parental cottage lay .

While yet many score yards off , other rhythmic sounds than those [she]636-her had quitted became audible to [her]636-her ; sounds that [she]636-her knew well - so well . They were a regular series of thumpings from the interior of [the house]652-the house , occasioned by the violent rocking of a cradle upon a stone floor , to which movement a feminine voice kept time by singing , in a vigorous gallopade , the favourite ditty of " The Spotted Cow "[0-i] -

[I]0-i saw [her]653-thy lie do'-own in yon'-der green gro'-ove ; Come , love ! ' and [I]0-i 'll tell ' [you]647-the girl where ! '

The cradle - rocking and the song would cease simultaneously for a moment , and an exclamation at highest vocal pitch would take the place of the melody .

" God bless [thy]653-thy diment eyes ! And [thy]653-thy waxen cheeks ! And [thy]653-thy cherry mouth ! And [thy]653-thy Cubit 's thighs ! And every bit o ' [thy]653-thy blessed body ! "[0-i]

After this invocation the rocking and the singing would recommence , and the " Spotted Cow "[0-i] proceed as before . So matters stood when [Tess]198-tess opened the door and paused upon the mat within [it]654-it , surveying the scene .

The interior , in spite of the melody , struck upon [the girl]647-the girl 's senses with an unspeakable dreariness . From the holiday gaieties of [the field]610-the field - the white gowns , the nosegays , the willow - wands , the whirling movements on the green , the flash of gentle sentiment towards [the stranger]657-the stranger - to the yellow melancholy of this one - candled spectacle , what a step ! Besides the jar of contrast there came to [her]636-her a chill self - reproach that [she]636-her had not returned sooner , to help [[her]636-her mother]658-her mother in these domesticities , instead of indulging [herself]636-her out - of - doors .

There stood [[her]636-her mother]658-her mother amid the group of [children]660-children , as [Tess]198-tess had left [her]658-her mother , hanging over the Monday washing - tub , which had now , as always , lingered on to the end of the week . Out of [that tub]661-that tub had come the day before - [Tess]198-tess felt it with a dreadful sting of remorse - the very white frock upon [her]198-tess back which [she]198-tess had so carelessly greened about the skirt on the damping grass - which had been wrung up and ironed by [[her]636-her mother]658-her mother 's own hands .

As usual , [Mrs Durbeyfield]180-mrs durbeyfield was balanced on one foot beside the tub , the other being engaged in the aforesaid business of rocking [[her]180-mrs durbeyfield youngest child]663-her youngest child . [The cradle - rockers]664-the cradle - rockers had done hard duty for so many years , under the weight of [so many children]665-so many children , on that flagstone floor , that they were worn nearly flat , in consequence of which a huge jerk accompanied each swing of the cot , flinging [the baby]666-the baby from side to side like [a weaver]667-a weaver 's shuttle , as [Mrs Durbeyfield]180-mrs durbeyfield , excited by [her]180-mrs durbeyfield song , trod the rocker with all the spring that was left in [her]180-mrs durbeyfield after a long day 's seething in the suds .

[Nick]204-nick - knock , nick - knock , went the cradle ; the candle - flame stretched itself tall , and began jigging up and down ; the water dribbled from [the matron]668-the matron 's elbows , and the song galloped on to the end of the verse , [Mrs Durbeyfield]180-mrs durbeyfield regarding [[her]180-mrs durbeyfield daughter]669-her daughter the while . Even now , when burdened with [a young family]670-a young family , [Joan Durbeyfield]205-joan was [a passionate lover of tune]671-a passionate lover of tune . No ditty floated into [Blackmoor Vale]53-blackmoor vale from [the outer world]672-the outer world but [[Tess]198-tess 's mother]673-tess 's mother caught up its notation in a week .

There still faintly beamed from [the woman]674-the woman 's features something of the freshness , and even the prettiness , of [her]674-the woman youth ; rendering it probable that the personal charms which [Tess]198-tess could boast of were in main part [[her]198-tess mother]658-her mother 's gift , and therefore unknightly , unhistorical .

" [I]676-the daughter 'll rock the cradle for ' ee , [mother]5917-mother , "[676-the daughter] said [the daughter]676-the daughter gently . To - night , however , [she]198-tess was even in a blither mood than usual . " And take [the Compleat Fortune - Teller]5950-the compleat fortune - teller to [the outhouse]5951-the outhouse , "[205-joan] [Joan]205-joan continued , rapidly wiping [her]205-joan hands , and donning the garments .

[The Compleat Fortune - Teller]5950-the compleat fortune - teller was an old thick volume , which lay on a table at [her]658-her mother elbow , so worn by pocketing that the margins had reached the edge of the type . [Tess]198-tess took it up , and [[her]198-tess mother]658-her mother started .

This going to hunt up [[her]658-her mother shiftless husband]696-her shiftless husband at [the inn]697-the inn was one of [Mrs Durbeyfield]180-mrs durbeyfield 's still extant enjoyments in the muck and muddle of rearing [children]660-children . To discover [him]696-her shiftless husband at [[Rolliver]211-rolliver 's]699-rolliver 's , to sit there for an hour or two by [his]696-her shiftless husband side and dismiss all thought and care of [the children]700-the children during the interval , made [her]198-tess happy . A sort of halo , an occidental glow , came over life then . Troubles and other realities took on themselves a metaphysical impalpability , sinking to mere mental phenomena for serene contemplation , and no longer stood as pressing concretions which chafed body and soul . [The youngsters , not immediately within sight , seemed rather bright and desirable appurtenances than otherwise]701-the youngsters , not immediately within sight , seemed rather bright and desirable appurtenances than otherwise ; the incidents of daily life were not without humorousness and jollity in their aspect there . [She]198-tess felt a little as [she]198-tess had used to feel when [she]198-tess sat by [[her]198-tess now wedded husband]702-her now wedded husband in the same spot during [his]702-her now wedded husband wooing , shutting [her]198-tess eyes to [his]702-her now wedded husband defects of character , and regarding [him]702-her now wedded husband only in [his]702-her now wedded husband ideal presentation as [lover]703-lover .

[Tess]198-tess , being left alone with [the younger children]704-the younger children , went first to [the outhouse]5951-the outhouse with the fortune - telling book , and stuffed it into the thatch . [[IV

Rolliver]215-iv rolliver 's inn]751-iv rolliver 's inn , [the single alehouse at this end of [the long and broken village]753-the long and broken village]752-the single alehouse at this end of the long and broken village , could only boast of an off - licence ; hence , as [nobody]754-nobody could legally drink on [the premises]755-the premises , the amount of overt accommodation for [consumers]756-consumers was strictly limited to a little board about six inches wide and two yards long , fixed to the garden palings by pieces of wire , so as to form a ledge . Thus [the strangers]759-the strangers . But there were also [local customers who felt the same wish]760-local customers who felt the same wish ; and where there 's a will there 's a way .

In [a large bedroom]761-a large bedroom [upstairs]762-upstairs , the window of which was thickly curtained with a great woollen shawl lately discarded by [the landlady]763-the landlady , [Mrs Rolliver]211-rolliver , were gathered on this evening nearly [a dozen persons]764-a dozen persons , all seeking beatitude ; [all old inhabitants of [the nearer end of [Marlott]21-marlott]766-the nearer end of marlott]765-all old inhabitants of the nearer end of marlott , and [frequenters of this retreat]767-frequenters of this retreat . [A gaunt four - post bedstead which stood in [the room]778-the room]777-a gaunt four - post bedstead which stood in the room afforded sitting - space for [several persons gathered round three of [its]777-a gaunt four - post bedstead which stood in the room sides]779-several persons gathered round three of its sides ; [a couple more men]780-a couple more men had elevated [themselves]780-a couple more men on a chest of drawers ; another rested on the oak - carved " cwoffer "[780-a couple more men] ; two on the wash - stand ; another on the stool ; and thus [all]622-all were , somehow , seated at [their]622-all ease . The stage of mental comfort to which [they]622-all had arrived at this hour was one wherein [their]622-all souls expanded beyond [their]622-all skins , and spread [their]622-all personalities warmly through [the room]778-the room . In this process [the chamber]783-the chamber and [its]783-the chamber furniture grew more and more dignified and luxurious ; the shawl hanging at the window took upon itself the richness of tapestry ; the brass handles of the chest of drawers were as golden knockers ; and the carved bedposts seemed to have some kinship with the magnificent pillars of [[Solomon]216-solomon 's temple]784-solomon 's temple .

[Mrs Durbeyfield]180-mrs durbeyfield , having quickly walked hitherward after parting from [Tess]198-tess , opened the front door , crossed [the downstairs room]785-the downstairs room , which was in deep gloom , and then unfastened the stair - door like one whose fingers knew the tricks of the latches well . [Her]180-mrs durbeyfield ascent of the crooked staircase was a slower process , and [her]180-mrs durbeyfield face , as it rose into the light above the last stair , encountered the gaze of [all the party assembled in [the bedroom]787-the bedroom]786-all the party assembled in the bedroom .

" - Being [a few private friends]5954-a few private friends [I]180-mrs durbeyfield 've asked in to keep up club - walking at [my]180-mrs durbeyfield own expense , "[180-mrs durbeyfield] [the landlady]763-the landlady exclaimed at the sound of footsteps , as glibly as [a child repeating the Catechism]789-a child repeating the catechism , while [she]180-mrs durbeyfield peered over the stairs . " Oh , ' tis [you]180-mrs durbeyfield , [Mrs Durbeyfield]180-mrs durbeyfield - Lard - how [you]180-mrs durbeyfield frightened [me]180-mrs durbeyfield ! - [I]180-mrs durbeyfield thought it might be some gaffer sent by [Gover'ment]217-gover'ment . "[180-mrs durbeyfield]

[Mrs Durbeyfield]180-mrs durbeyfield was welcomed with glances and nods by [the remainder of the conclave]790-the remainder of the conclave , and turned to where [[her]180-mrs durbeyfield husband]791-her husband sat . "[791-her husband]

" [I]792-his cheerful wife 've something to tell [']792-his cheerful wife [ee]792-his cheerful wife that 's come into [my]792-his cheerful wife head about that - a grand projick ! "[792-his cheerful wife] [She]792-his cheerful wife nudged [him]791-her husband , while [he]791-her husband , looking through [her]792-his cheerful wife as through a window - pane , went on with [his]791-her husband recitative .

" Hush ! "[763-the landlady]

" [He]791-her husband 's told ' [ee]792-his cheerful wife what 's happened to [us]5961-us , [I]180-mrs durbeyfield suppose ? "[180-mrs durbeyfield] asked [Mrs Durbeyfield]180-mrs durbeyfield .

" Yes - in a way . D'ye think there 's any money hanging by it ? "[792-his cheerful wife]

Though this conversation had been private , sufficient of its import reached the understandings of [those around]797-those around to suggest to [them]797-those around that [the Durbeyfields]218-the durbeyfields had weightier concerns to talk of now than [common folks]798-common folks had , and that [Tess]198-tess , [[their]218-the durbeyfields pretty eldest daughter]799-their pretty eldest daughter , had fine prospects in store .

" - Being [a few private friends]5954-a few private friends asked in to - night to keep up club - walking at [my]763-the landlady own expense . Even to [[her]198-tess mother]658-her mother 's gaze [the girl]647-the girl 's young features looked sadly out of place amid the alcoholic vapours which floated here as no unsuitable medium for wrinkled middle - age ; and hardly was a reproachful flash from [Tess]198-tess 's dark eyes needed to make [[her]198-tess father]557-her father and [mother]5917-mother rise from [their]809-their seats , hastily finish [their]809-their ale , and descend the stairs behind [her]198-tess , [Mrs Rolliver]211-rolliver 's caution following [their]809-their footsteps .

[They]809-their went [home]5850-home together , [Tess]198-tess holding one arm of [[her]198-tess father]557-her father , and [Mrs Durbeyfield]180-mrs durbeyfield the other . [He]557-her father had , in truth , drunk very little - not a fourth of the quantity which [a systematic tippler]812-a systematic tippler could carry to [church]813-church on a Sunday afternoon without a hitch in [his]557-her father eastings or genuflections ; but the weakness of [Sir John]177-sir john 's constitution made mountains of [his]557-her father petty sins in this kind . "[816-the head of the family]

[Tess]198-tess turned the subject by saying what was far more prominent in [her]198-tess own mind at the moment than thoughts of [her]198-tess ancestry - " [I]198-tess am afraid [father]5842-father wo n't be able to take the journey with the beehives to - morrow so early . "[198-tess]

" [I]198-tess ? [I]198-tess shall be all right in an hour or two , "[198-tess] said [Durbeyfield]198-tess .

It was eleven o'clock before [the family]719-the family were all in bed , and two o'clock next morning was the latest hour for starting with the beehives if they were to be delivered to [the retailers in [Casterbridge]41-casterbridge]821-the retailers in casterbridge before the Saturday market began , the way thither lying by [bad roads]822-bad roads over a distance of between twenty and thirty miles , and the horse and waggon being of the slowest . " [The poor man]5941-the poor man ca n't go , "[180-mrs durbeyfield] [she]180-mrs durbeyfield said to [[her]180-mrs durbeyfield eldest daughter]826-her eldest daughter , whose great eyes had opened the moment [[her]826-her eldest daughter mother]658-her mother 's hand touched the door .

[Tess]198-tess sat up in bed , lost in a vague interspace between a dream and this information .

" But [somebody]6000-somebody must go , "[198-tess] [she]198-tess replied . " It is late for the hives already . Swarming will soon be over for the year ; and it [we]6001-we put off taking 'em till next week 's market the call for 'em will be past , and they 'll be thrown on [our]6001-we hands . "[198-tess]

" O no - [I]198-tess would n't have it for [the world]497-the world ! "[198-tess] declared [Tess]198-tess proudly . " And letting [everybody]569-everybody know the reason - such a thing to be ashamed of ! [[Her]198-tess mother]658-her mother at length agreed to this arrangement . [Little Abraham]212-abraham was aroused from [his]212-abraham deep sleep in [a corner of [the same apartment]830-the same apartment]829-a corner of the same apartment , and made to put on [his]212-abraham clothes while still mentally in [the other world]831-the other world . Meanwhile [Tess]198-tess had hastily dressed [herself]198-tess ; and [the twain , lighting a lantern]832-the twain , lighting a lantern , went out to [the stable]833-the stable . [The rickety little waggon]834-the rickety little waggon was already laden , and [the girl]647-the girl led out the horse , [Prince]223-prince , only a degree less rickety than [the vehicle]836-the vehicle .

[The poor creature]837-the poor creature looked wonderingly round at the night , at the lantern , at [[their]838-they two figures]839-their two figures , as if [he]837-the poor creature could not believe that at that hour , when every living thing was intended to be in shelter and at rest , [he]837-the poor creature was called upon to go out and labour . [They]838-they put a stock of candle - ends into the lantern , hung the latter to the off - side of the load , and directed the horse onward , walking at [his]837-the poor creature shoulder at first during the uphill parts of the way , in order not to overload an animal of so little vigour . To cheer [themselves]838-they as well as [they]838-they could , [they]838-they made an artificial morning with the lantern , some bread and butter , and [their]838-they own conversation , the real morning being far from come . [Abraham]212-abraham , as [he]212-abraham more fully awoke for [he]212-abraham had moved in a sort of trance so far , began to talk of the strange shapes assumed by the various dark objects against the sky ; of this tree that looked like a raging tiger springing from a lair ; of that which resembled a giant 's head .

When [they]838-they had passed [the little town of [Stourcastle]32-stourcastle]840-the little town of stourcastle , dumbly somnolent under its thick brown thatch , [they]838-they reached higher ground . Still higher , on [their]838-they left , the elevation called Bulbarrow , or [Bealbarrow]42-bealbarrow , well - nigh [the highest in [South Wessex]43-south wessex]841-the highest in south wessex , swelled into the sky , engirdled by [its]842-its earthen trenches . From hereabout [the long road]843-the long road was fairly level for some distance onward . [They]838-they mounted in front of the waggon , and [Abraham]212-abraham grew reflective .

" [Tess]198-tess ! "[212-abraham] [he]212-abraham said in a preparatory tone , after a silence .

" Yes , [Abraham]212-abraham . "[845-his sister]

" [I]845-his sister ? [[Our]838-they great relation]6009-our great relation ? [We]838-they have no such relation . What has put that into [your]212-abraham head ? "[845-his sister]
